svg.text: How to Fix Your Entire Life in 1 Day
7 Ideas on Behavior Change, Psychology & Productivity
"If you want a specific outcome in life, you must have the lifestyle that creates that outcome long before you reach it."
I ‚Äî YOU AREN'T WHERE YOU WANT TO BE BECAUSE YOU AREN'T THE PERSON WHO WOULD BE THERE
Two Requirements for Success
‚Ä¢ Changing your actions to make progress toward the goal (least important, second order)
‚Ä¢ Changing who you are so that your behavior naturally follows (most important, first order)
The Bodybuilder Example
Does the bodybuilder have to "grind" to eat healthy?
The truth is they can't see themselves living any other way.
The bodybuilder has to grind to eat unhealthily.
The CEO Example
Does the CEO have to discipline themselves to show up and lead?
They have to force themselves to lie in bed past their alarm clock,
and they hate every second of it.
"If I weren't having fun, why would I be doing what I'm doing?"
"If someone says they want to lose 30 pounds... but they say 'I can't wait until I'm done losing weight
so I can start to enjoy life again' ‚Äî they will go straight back to where they started."
II ‚Äî YOU AREN'T WHERE YOU WANT TO BE BECAUSE YOU DON'T WANT TO BE THERE
"Trust only movement. Life happens at the level of events, not of words. Trust movement." ‚Äî Alfred Adler
All Behavior is Goal-Oriented (Teleological)
‚Ä¢ You take a step forward because you want to reach a certain location
‚Ä¢ You scratch your nose because you want to make the itch go away
‚Ä¢ Most of the time, your goals are unconscious
Procrastination Example
You may justify it as "lacking discipline" but in reality you are
pursuing a goal: protecting yourself from judgment.
Dead-End Job Example
You pursue the goal of safety, predictability, and an excuse
to not look like a failure to everyone else.
III ‚Äî YOU AREN'T WHERE YOU WANT TO BE BECAUSE YOU'RE AFRAID TO BE THERE
The Anatomy of Identity
1. You want to achieve a goal
2. You perceive reality through the lens of that goal
3. You only notice "important" information that allows you to achieve that goal (learning)
4. You act toward that goal and receive feedback that you are progressing toward it
5. You repeat that behavior until it becomes automatic and unconscious (conditioning)
6. That behavior becomes a part of who you think you are ("I am the type of person who...")
7. You defend your identity to maintain psychological consistency
8. Your identity shapes new goals, restarting the cycle
‚Üí Break the cycle between steps 6 and 7
When your body feels threatened, you go into fight or flight.
When your identity feels threatened, the same thing happens.
"You literally feel the stress. You feel, emotionally, like you were just slapped in the face."
"If you were raised in a religious household, and did not think for yourself, you will fight and attack others who threaten your psychological safety."
IV ‚Äî THE LIFE YOU WANT LIES WITHIN A SPECIFIC LEVEL OF MIND
9 Stages of Ego Development
1. Impulsive
No separation between impulse and action. Black and white thinking.
2. Self-Protective
The world is dangerous and you learn to look out for yourself.
3. Conformist
You are your group and its rules feel like reality itself.
4. Self-Aware
You notice you have an inner life that doesn't match the exterior.
5. Conscientious
You build your own system of principles and hold yourself accountable.
6. Individualist
Your principles were shaped by context, hold them more loosely.
7. Strategist
Work with systems while aware of your own involvement in them.
8. Construct-Aware
All frameworks, including your identity, as useful fictions.
9. Unitive
Separation between self and life dissolves. Just presence responding.
Key Insight
For most people reading this, I would
assume you hover between 4 and 8.
The good thing is, it doesn't really matter
what stage you are in, because moving
through any of them follows a pattern.
"Work, rest, and play feel like the
same thing. There's no one left who
needs to become something, just
presence responding to what arises."
V ‚Äî INTELLIGENCE IS THE ABILITY TO GET WHAT YOU WANT OUT OF LIFE
"The only real test of intelligence is if you get what you want out of life." ‚Äî Naval Ravikant
Formula for Success
‚Ä¢ Agency ‚Äî the likelihood to act toward a goal
‚Ä¢ Opportunity ‚Äî which many people like to mistake as "privilege"
‚Ä¢ Intelligence ‚Äî understanding cybernetics: "the art of getting what you want"
Cybernetics: The Intelligent System
1. To have a goal
2. Act toward that goal
3. Sense where you are
4. Compare it to the goal
5. And act again based on that feedback
To Become More Intelligent
‚Ä¢ Reject the known path
‚Ä¢ Dive into the unknown
‚Ä¢ Set new, higher goals to expand your mind
‚Ä¢ Embrace the chaos and allow for growth
‚Ä¢ Study generalized principles, become a deep generalist
VI ‚Äî HOW TO LAUNCH INTO A COMPLETELY NEW LIFE (IN 1 DAY)
3 Phases of Identity Flip
1. Dissonance
They feel like they don't belong in their current life,
become sufficiently fed up with their lack of progress.
2. Uncertainty
They don't know what comes next, so they either
experiment or get lost and feel worse.
3. Discovery
They discover what they want to pursue and
make 6 years of progress in 6 months.
üåÖ PART 1: MORNING ‚Äî PSYCHOLOGICAL EXCAVATION ‚Äî VISION & ANTI-VISION
Questions to Uncover Pain
‚Ä¢ What is the dull and persistent dissatisfaction you've learned to live with?
‚Ä¢ What do you complain about repeatedly but never actually change?
‚Ä¢ What truth about your current life would be unbearable to admit to someone you deeply respect?
Create Anti-Vision (The Life You Don't Want)
‚Ä¢ If absolutely nothing changes for the next 5 years, describe an average Tuesday.
‚Ä¢ Now do it for 10 years. What have you missed? What opportunities closed?
‚Ä¢ You're at the end of your life. You lived the safe version. What was the cost?
‚Ä¢ Who in your life is already living the future you just described?
‚Ä¢ What identity would you have to give up to actually change?
‚Ä¢ What is the most embarrassing reason you haven't changed?
Create Vision MVP
‚Ä¢ Forget practicality. If you could snap your fingers and be living a different life in 3 years, what does an average Tuesday look like?
‚Ä¢ What would you have to believe about yourself for that life to feel natural?
‚Ä¢ Write the identity statement: "I am the type of person who..."
‚Ä¢ What is one thing you would do this week if you were already that person?
"The best periods of my life always came after a period of getting absolutely fed up with the lack of progress I was making."
‚òÄÔ∏è PART 2: THROUGHOUT THE DAY ‚Äî INTERRUPTING AUTOPILOT ‚Äî BREAKING UNCONSCIOUS PATTERNS
Set Calendar Reminders with These Questions
11:00am: What am I avoiding right now by doing what I'm doing?
1:30pm: If someone filmed the last two hours, what would they conclude that I want from my life?
3:15pm: Am I moving toward the life I hate or the life I want?
5:00pm: What's the most important thing I'm pretending isn't important?
7:30pm: What did I do today out of identity protection rather than genuine desire?
9:00pm: When did I feel most alive today? When did I feel most dead?
Deeper Questions (Schedule During Commuting or Walking)
‚Ä¢ What would change if I stopped needing people to see me as [identity]? ‚Ä¢ Where am I trading aliveness for safety?
üåô PART 3: EVENING ‚Äî SYNTHESIZING INSIGHT ‚Äî ENTERING A SEASON OF PROGRESS
Synthesis Questions
‚Ä¢ After today, what feels most true about why you've been stuck?
‚Ä¢ What is the actual enemy? Name it clearly. Not circumstances. Not other people. The internal pattern or belief.
‚Ä¢ Write a single sentence that captures what you refuse to let your life become. (Anti-vision compressed)
‚Ä¢ Write a single sentence that captures what you're building toward. (Vision MVP)
Create Goals (As Lenses, Not Finish Lines)
‚Ä¢ One-year lens: What would have to be true in one year for you to know you've broken the old pattern?
‚Ä¢ One-month lens: What would have to be true in one month for the one-year lens to remain possible?
‚Ä¢ Daily lens: What are 2-3 actions you can timeblock tomorrow that the person you're becoming would simply do?
"Think of goals as a point of view. A lens that you can exchange to enter the right state of mind to perform the action."
VII ‚Äî TURN YOUR LIFE INTO A VIDEO GAME
"The optimal state of inner experience is one in which there is order in consciousness. This happens when psychic energy
‚Äî or attention ‚Äî is invested in realistic goals, and when skills match the opportunities for action." ‚Äî Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi
6 Components of Your Life Game
Life Component
Game Element
Description
Anti-Vision
What's at stake if you lose
The bane of your existence
Vision
How you win
The ideal life you can improve as you work toward it
1 Year Goal
The mission
Your sole priority in life
1 Month Project
The boss fight
How you gain XP and acquire loot
Daily Levers
The quests
The daily process that unlocks new opportunities
Constraints
The rules
Limitations that encourage creativity
"The more you play the game, the stronger this force becomes, and soon enough it becomes who you are."
üíé KEY TAKEAWAY
"Real change requires changing your goals ‚Äî not setting surface-level goals,
but changing your point of view. A goal is a lens of perception."
"You will not see anything else as an option."
Source: "How to Fix Your Entire Life in 1 Day" by Dan Koe | Mindmap Design by Yak0xff
